questions.text: An infectious disease has its incubation period as 5-14 days, with its median incubation period being 10 days. The quarantine of contacts traveling to a new country should be done for: [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) 14 days


Quarantine is the process of separating and restricting the movement of healthy individuals who may have been exposed to an infectious disease, to prevent its spread. Quarantine is typically implemented for the maximum incubation period of the disease, which is the time between exposure to the infection and the onset of symptoms.

 

In this case, the maximum incubation period is 14 days. Therefore, quarantine should be conducted for 14 days to ensure that if symptoms develop, they will appear within this period, confirming the need for isolation and treatment.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Quarantine should be conducted for the maximum incubation period of the infectious disease to ensure that symptoms will manifest within that time, confirming whether a contact becomes a case.

questions.text: For Health Education, the Motivation Model has its 1st  Step as Awareness. Its 2nd  Step is Motivation. Its 3rd  Step is: [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Action

 

The Motivation Model for Health Education comprises three steps:

 

  1. Awareness: This step involves generating interest in the person’s mind about the health topic or problem.
  2. Motivation: This stage includes evaluation and decision-making, where the person is encouraged and motivated to consider the health information or behavior change.
  3. Action: This is the final step where the individual accepts and adopts the health idea or practice. The person moves from motivation to implementation, engaging in the recommended health behavior.

 

Other 2 Models are –

 

  • Medical Model – This involves interaction between the patient and doctor, where the patient presents their illness, and the doctor diagnoses it as a disease.
  • Social Interactive Model

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dedication: Dedication is not explicitly a step in the Motivation Model but can be an outcome of sustained action and commitment to the behavior change.

 

Option C. Contemplation: Contemplation is a stage in other health behavior change models, such as the Transtheoretical Model, where individuals consider changing but do not yet take action. It is not the third step in the Motivation Model.

 

Option D. Reflection: Reflection is not part of the Motivation Model’s steps. It typically refers to thinking back on actions and decisions, often occurring after the behavior has been implemented.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The third step in the Motivation Model for Health Education is Action, which signifies the adoption and implementation of the health behavior.

questions.text: The time gap between entry of organism in human body and its maximal infectivity is: [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Generation time

 

Generation time is defined as the time interval between the entry of an infectious organism into the human body and the period when the individual reaches maximal infectivity. This concept is crucial in understanding the spread of infectious diseases, as it indicates when an infected person is most likely to transmit the infection to others.

 

Generation time helps public health professionals predict the spread of disease and is essential in planning control measures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Incubation period: This option is incorrect. The incubation period is the time from exposure to the onset of first sign/symptom, not specifically related to the peak of infectivity.

 

Option B. Median IP: This option is incorrect. Median incubation period refers to the time by which 50% of cases exhibit symptoms, unrelated to infectivity.

 

Option C.  Serial IP (Serial Interval Period): This option is incorrect. The serial interval measures the gap between symptom onset in a primary case and a secondary case, not between entry of the organism and peak infectivity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Generation time is the interval between the entry of an organism into the body and the point of maximal infectivity.

questions.text: As a physician on a disaster preparedness committee in a region prone to natural disasters, you are discussing the appropriate sequence of actions following a disaster. Which of the following sequences correctly represents the appropriate steps in disaster management after the event has taken place? [AIIMS MAY 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Response – Rehabilitation – Reconstruction – Mitigation – Preparedness

 

The correct sequence after a disaster as per the general disaster management principles is:

 

  1. Response: Immediate actions taken to ensure safety, provide emergency services, and stabilize the situation. This involves –
    • Search, rescue and first aid
    • Field care
    • Triage
    • Tagging
    • Identification of dead
  2. Rehabilitation: Short-term recovery and normalization of operations to restore basic services and functions in the affected area.
  3. Reconstruction: Long-term rebuilding of infrastructure and restoration of a fully functional community.
  4. Mitigation: Efforts to reduce the risk and lessen the impact of future disasters.
  5. Preparedness: Planning and preparation to improve response activities for future disasters.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Disaster Cycle

questions.text: An individual seeks to explore the correlation between smoking and lung cancer. To do so, they gather information on individuals diagnosed with lung cancer from government hospitals, along with data on the quantity of cigarette packets sold during the corresponding timeframe. What category of study does this represent? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Ecological

 

In the given study, the unit of study is the population, and the data collected by the investigator is secondary in nature. Therefore, this type of study is an ecological study, also known as a correlational study.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cross-Sectional Study: Involves collecting data at a single point in time from individuals to assess the prevalence of an outcome or characteristic.

 

  • The unit of analysis is the individual, not the population.

 

Option C. Experimental Study: Involves the researcher manipulating one or more variables to observe the effect on an outcome.

 

  • There is no experimental intervention in the given study scenario.

 

Option D. Quasi-Experimental Study: Involves an intervention but lacks random assignment of participants to treatment or control groups.

 

  • Similar to experimental studies, quasi-experimental studies involve individuals, not population-level data.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ECOLOGICAL STUDY / CO-RELATIONAL STUDY

 

  • Done at a point of time [E.g. in 2023]
  • Used in Nutritional surveys, e.g. à Avg. fat intake = 20gm/day
  • Can’t calculate strength of Association or Prevalence
  • Based on secondary data [collected by someone else, studied by investigator]

questions.text: A 30-year-old resident physician was exposed to HIV through a needlestick injury and has come to the emergency department seeking help. You decide to start her on post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP). Which of the following drug combinations is most recommended for PEP in this scenario? [AIIMS MAY 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Lamivudine + Tenofovir + Dolutegravir for 4 weeks 

 

  • Post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) is an emergency treatment for HIV exposure, typically recommended to be started as soon as possible after exposure, ideally within 2 hours and no later than 72 hours.
  • The choice of antiretroviral therapy for PEP should be guided by current recommendations that prioritize effectiveness and tolerability.
  • Lamivudine + Tenofovir + Dolutegravir (Option B): This combination is currently recommended for PEP due to its high efficacy, good tolerability, and strong safety profile. Tenofovir and Lamivudine provide a potent backbone of nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs), while Dolutegravir acts as an integrase strand transfer inhibitor (INSTI), which has a rapid onset of action and is well-tolerated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Post Exposure Prophylaxis HIV

 

Preferably within 24 hours. Maximum within 72 hours.

 

Duration of prophylaxis is 28 days

questions.text: During a medical ethics seminar, Dr. Sharma discussed a series of international declarations that guide medical professionals in upholding ethical principles in various scenarios. These declarations were born out of historical events and societal needs to ensure the welfare of patients and respect human rights. Can you match these declarations with their respective significance? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) I - C, II - D, III - A, IV - B

 

  • Geneva Declaration: It is primarily focused on the physician's dedication to the humanitarian goals of medicine, emphasizing the commitment of the medical profession to human welfare and ethics. This declaration is assigned significance C.
  • Oslo Declaration: It deals with issues surrounding therapeutic abortion, offering guidelines and ethical considerations for medical professionals when abortion is a factor in medical treatment. This declaration is assigned significance D.
  • Tokyo Declaration: Provides guidelines for physicians concerning the ethical treatment of detainees and prisoners, specifically regarding torture and other forms of cruel, inhuman, or degrading treatment. This declaration is assigned significance A.
  • Helsinki Declaration: A cornerstone document that outlines ethical principles for the medical community concerning human experimentation. This declaration provides comprehensive guidelines intended to protect the dignity, rights, safety, and well-being of research subjects. It is assigned significance B.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: As a healthcare consultant in Uttar Pradesh working to improve maternal and child health outcomes, you need to address issues such as inadequate hygiene, lack of skilled staff, and outdated equipment in labor rooms of public health facilities. Which program should you recommend that is specifically designed to enhance the quality of labor rooms? [AIIMS MAY 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) LAQSHYA

 

LAQSHYA [Labour Room Quality Improvement Initiative] 

 

  • MoHFW launched LaQshya to improve the quality of care that is being provided to the pregnant mother in the Labor Room and Maternity Operation Theaters, thereby preventing the undesirable adverse outcomes associated with childbirth
  • Aim: To reduce Maternal and newborn mortality & morbidity and stillbirths
  • Coverage: Govt Medical colleges & hospitals/District hospitals/FRU > 100 deliveries/month, High load CHC (>60 deliveries/month)

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ayushman Bharat: This is a broader health insurance scheme aimed at providing health cover to underprivileged families, not specifically focused on improving labor room conditions.

 

Option C. Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram: Although this program provides free benefits to pregnant women and sick infants, it does not specifically target the improvement of labor room conditions.

 

Option D. Pradhan Mantri Surakshit Matritva Abhiyan: This initiative is aimed at providing assured, comprehensive, and quality antenatal care, free of cost, to pregnant women on the 9th of every month but does not specifically address labor room quality improvement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Recommending the LAQSHYA program is directly aligned with the need to overhaul the quality of labor rooms in public health facilities, targeting specific improvements in infrastructure, hygiene, and staff competencies to ensure safer childbirth experiences.

questions.text: Which of these methods relies on behavioral sciences? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Management by objective

 

Management by objective (MBO) is a technique based on behavioral sciences. It was developed by Peter Drucker in the 1950s and emphasizes the importance of setting clear goals and objectives that are aligned with organizational goals, and then measuring progress towards achieving those objectives.

 

MBO is based on the idea that individuals are motivated by the achievement of goals and that they perform better when they know what is expected of them. The technique involves a participatory process where employees are involved in setting their own goals and objectives, which are then reviewed and evaluated by their managers. This approach is intended to improve communication and collaboration within organizations, and to help employees feel more engaged and motivated in their work.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decision making:  This can rely on both behavioral sciences and quantitative methods, but in the context of management and organizational processes, it often involves analytical and quantitative approaches.

 

Option B. Systems analysis:  This is a quantitative method used to understand and analyze complex systems and processes, often involving mathematical models and simulations.

 

Option C. Network analysis:  This is a quantitative method used to plan and control complex projects, involving techniques like PERT (Program Evaluation and Review Technique) and CPM (Critical Path Method).

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Sensitivity will decrease, specificity will increase
Sensitivity will increase, specificity will decrease

questions.text: You are assessing the impact of a new series testing protocol on the performance characteristics of diagnostic tests for a specific disease. You need to explain to your team how this method affects the test's sensitivity and specificity. What would be the correct explanation? [AIIMS MAY 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Sensitivity will decrease, specificity will increase

 

SCREENING TESTS USED IN SERIES:

 

A population is subjected to one screening test followed by a second screening test; 2nd screening test is applied on those individuals only who test positive on the 1st screening test

 

  • Combined sensitivity of 2 tests A & B in series: Sensitivity (A) × Sensitivity (B)
  • Combined specificity of 2 tests A & B in series: [Specificity (A) + Specificity (B)] – [Specificity (A) × Specificity (B)]

 

SCREENING TESTS USED IN PARALLEL:

 

A population is subjected to two (or more) screening tests at the same time; each of the individuals is subjected to both (or all) screening tests

 

  • Combined sensitivity of 2 tests A & B in parallel: [Sensitivity (A) + Sensitivity (B)] – [Sensitivity (A) × Sensitivity (B)]
  • Combined specificity of 2 tests A & B in parallel: Specificity (A) × Specificity (B)

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: As the in-charge epidemiologist of an urban CHC, you've been reviewing the weekly infectious disease reports. In a particular community under your jurisdiction, you observe that dengue case counts typically range from 40 to 50 cases every week. During your current weekly review, you note there are 48 reported cases of dengue. Based on this data and your understanding of epidemiological terminology, how would you classify this week's situation with respect to dengue? [AIIMS MAY 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Endemic 

 

  • The given scenario is an example of an endemic disease.

 

Endemic

 

  • Endemic: Constant presence of a disease or infectious agent in a defined geographical area. It is the ‘usual or expected frequency’ of a disease in a population
  • Types of Endemic:
    • Hyper-endemic: Constant presence of a disease or infectious agent at high incidence/prevalence AND affects all age groups equally
    • Holo-endemic: A high level of infection beginning early in life AND affecting most of the children population

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Epidemic: Incorrect because an epidemic refers to an increase in the number of cases of a disease beyond what is normally expected in that population in that area. The current case count does not exceed the usual range.

 

Option C. Sporadic: Incorrect because sporadic refers to a disease that occurs infrequently and irregularly; here, the cases are neither infrequent nor irregular.

 

Option D. Outbreak: Similar to an epidemic, an outbreak implies a greater-than-anticipated increase in the number of cases within a small, localized area over a short period. Again, since the case count is within normal expectations, this term does not apply.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Endemic: Is the ‘usual or expected frequency’ of a disease in a population

choices.text: Not more than 10% of the people benefitted by the drug could be due to chance
90% of patients will be benefitted by giving the drug
90% of test results could have occurred by chance

questions.text: An investigative study was conducted in Mumbai wherein a promising new antihypertensive medication was evaluated for its potential efficacy. Initial clinical trials with a diverse cohort of patients with chronic hypertension revealed promising results in managing elevated blood pressure levels. The efficacy of the drug was measured meticulously, and upon analyzing the data, a p-value of < 0.10 was documented. Given this statistical information and considering the nuances of research interpretation, which of the following statements best elucidates the implications of this p-value in terms of the drug's effect? [AIIMS MAY 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Not more than 10% of the people benefitted by the drug could be due to chance

 

  • A P-value of less than 0.10 suggests that the likelihood of the drug's benefits occurring due to chance is no higher than 10%.

 

 INTERPRETATION:

 

  • Out of 100 repeated tests, a statistically insignificant difference will occur only 10 times, while a statistically significant difference will emerge 90 times.
  • There is a 10% probability of incorrectly concluding that a drug is beneficial when it is not, which can happen in statistical studies when deciding whether to accept or reject a null hypothesis.
  • The P value is compared to a predetermined threshold value 'a'; if the P value is less than 'a', the test is considered statistically significant, and the null hypothesis is rejected.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The p-value is a statistical parameter used to evaluate whether the results of an experiment are statistically significant.
  • In this case, a p-value of < 0.10 suggests there is up to a 10% chance that the observed benefits from the antihypertensive drug could be due to random variation rather than a true effect of the drug.

questions.text: According to NCEP-ATP III guidelines, which of the options below is not considered a criterion for metabolic syndrome? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) High LDL

 

High LDL: This is not a criterion for metabolic syndrome according to the NCEP-ATP III guidelines. While high LDL cholesterol is a significant risk factor for cardiovascular disease, it is not part of the metabolic syndrome criteria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypertriglyceridemia: Elevated triglyceride levels are a criterion for metabolic syndrome and indicate dyslipidemia.

 

Option C. Central Obesity: Defined by waist circumference, this is a key criterion for metabolic syndrome and indicates visceral fat accumulation.

 

Option D. Hypertension: Elevated blood pressure is included in the criteria for metabolic syndrome, reflecting its association with increased cardiovascular risk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

According to NCEP-ATP III guidelines, criterion for metabolic syndromes are:

questions.text: Which of the following variables indicates the difference between the incidence of disease among exposed and incidence among non-exposed? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Attributable risk

 

The difference between the incidence of disease among exposed and the incidence among non-exposed is given by the attributable risk. Attributable risk is the difference in risk of disease between two groups (exposed and non-exposed) and represents the proportion of disease occurrence that can be attributed to the exposure.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  Relative risk: Is a measure of the strength of association between exposure and disease, and it compares the risk of disease in exposed individuals to the risk in non-exposed individuals.

 

Option C. Population attributable risk: Is a measure of the Incidence of the disease that is likely to be reduced if the risk factor is modified/eliminated.

 

 

Option D. Odds ratio: Is a measure of the odds of exposure among cases compared to the odds of exposure among controls in a case-control study.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Attributable risk is the metric that indicates the difference in the incidence of disease between exposed and non-exposed groups, representing the proportion of disease occurrence attributable to the exposure.

questions.text: During a major disaster response, the medical team in an emergency department needs to prioritize patients based on the severity of their injuries and their medical needs. This prioritization process is known as triage. Each patient is assigned a specific color code representing their current state and the urgency of their medical attention. Which of the following correctly matches the color designation with its corresponding level of patient priority in the triage process? [AIIMS MAY 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Green – ambulatory

 

  • Triage is a critical process used in emergency medicine to quickly classify patients according to the severity of their health condition and the urgency of their need for care.
  • The color-coding system is a standardized approach used globally, with each color representing a specific category of priority:
  • Green indicates "ambulatory" patients, who are those with relatively minor injuries or conditions that do not require immediate, life-saving intervention.
  • These patients can often walk and may have injuries such as infections, closed fractures, minor abrasions, and lacerations.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: You are overseeing the arrival of vaccines at a remote clinic. To ensure the vaccines have maintained their potency during transit, which tool would you use? [AIIMS MAY 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Vaccine vial monitor

 

  • Vaccine vial monitors (VVM) are heat-sensitive indicators routinely used to monitor heat exposure of the vaccine and determine vaccine viability as the vaccine vial moves across the supply chain.
  • VVMs change color as the vaccine is exposed to cumulative heat. If the color of inner square is similar or darker than the outer circle, the vaccine vial should be discarded.
  • A VVM can be used to assess vaccine potency and not vaccine efficacy.
  • Expiry date can’t be determined by VVM and has no relation to extend the expiry date.
  • If the square and the circle are the same in colour or square is darker, then the vaccine should be discarded.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. e-VIN: e-VIN (Electronic Vaccine Intelligence Network) tracks the stock status and temperature of vaccine inventories via the internet, but it does not assess the viability of individual vaccine vials upon arrival.

 

Option B. Freeze indicator: Freeze indicator detects exposure to freezing temperatures, which can damage vaccines, but it does not indicate heat exposure.

 

Option D. Fridge indicator: Fridge indicator monitors the temperature inside a refrigerator, ensuring it remains within a safe range but does not provide specific information about the exposure of individual vaccine vials during transport.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of School Health under Ayushman Bharat Program? [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Monthly IFA supplementations

 

The Ayushman Bharat Program includes a comprehensive school health component aimed at improving the health and hygiene of school children. The key components include:

 

  • Weekly Iron Folic Acid Supplementation (WIFS): This involves the distribution of iron and folic acid supplements on a weekly basis to prevent anemia among school children. Monthly supplementation is not part of this program; hence, "Monthly IFA supplementations" is the incorrect option.
  • Sanitary Napkins Distribution: Under the menstrual hygiene scheme, sanitary napkins branded as "Freedays" are distributed to adolescent girls to promote menstrual hygiene.
  • Albendazole for Deworming: Deworming through albendazole is conducted to reduce the prevalence of intestinal worm infestations among school-aged children.
  • Health Check-ups: Regular health screenings are conducted to assess the physical and mental fitness of students, ensuring early identification and management of health issues.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Ayushman Bharat School Health Program includes weekly IFA supplementation, not monthly, along with other health initiatives like menstrual hygiene, deworming, screening health check-ups, physical & mental fitness, Research and Vaccination

choices.text: Village Health Planning and Management Committee
Village Health Sanitation and Nutrition Committee

questions.text: As part of a health development project in rural India, you're asked about the key community group responsible for overseeing local health, sanitation, and nutrition initiatives. Which committee best fits this description? [AIIMS MAY 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Village Health Sanitation and Nutrition Committee

 

  • One of the key elements of the National Rural Health Mission is the Village Health, Sanitation and Nutrition committee (VHSNC).
  • The committee has been formed to take collective actions on issues related to health and its social determinants at the village level.
  • They are particularly envisaged as being central to ‘local level community action’ under NRHM, which would develop to support the process of Decentralized Health Planning.
  • Thus VHSNC is envisaged to take leadership in providing a platform for improving health awareness and access of community for health services, address specific local needs and serve as a mechanism for community based planning and monitoring.
  • The committee is formed at the revenue village level and it should act as a sub-committee of the Gram Panchayat.
  • It should have a minimum of 15 members which should comprise of elected member of the Panchayat who shall lead the committee, all those working for health and health related services should participate, community members/ beneficiaries and representation from all community sub-groups especially the vulnerable sections and hamlets/ habitations. ASHA residing in the village shall be the member secretary and convener of the committee.

 

 ROLES AND RESPONSIBILITIES 

 

  • Create awareness about nutritional issues and significance of nutrition as an important determinant of health.
  • Carry out survey on nutritional status and nutritional deficiencies in the village especially among women and children.
  • Identify locally available food stuffs of high nutrient value as well as disseminate and promote best practices (traditional wisdom) congruent with local culture, capabilities and physical environment through a process of community consultation.
  • Inclusion of Nutritional needs in the Village Health Plan – The committee will do an in-depth analysis of causes of malnutrition at the community and household levels, by involving the ANM, AWW, ASHA and ICDS Supervisors.
  • Monitoring and Supervision of Village Health and Nutrition Day to ensure that it is organized every month in the village with the active participation of the whole village.
  • Facilitate early detection of malnourished children in the community; tie up referral to the nearest Nutritional Rehabilitation Centre (NRC) as well as follow up for sustained outcome.
  • Supervise the functioning of Anganwadi Centre (AWC) in the village and facilitate its working in improving nutritional status of women and children.
  • Act as a grievances redressal forum on health and nutrition issues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Panchayat Health Committee and Option B. Village Health Planning and Management Committee generally refer to broader terms, but they do not specifically target the integrated approach of the VHSNC.

 

Option C. Rogi Kalyan Samiti (Patient Welfare Committee) / Hospital Management Committee is a simple yet effective management structure. This committee, a registered society, acts as a group of trustees for the hospitals to manage the affairs of the hospital. It consists of members from local Panchayati Raj Institutions (PRIs), NGOs, local elected representatives and officials from Government sector who are responsible for proper functioning and management of the hospital / Community Health Centre / FRUs. RKS / HMS is free to prescribe, generate and use the funds with it as per its best judgement for smooth functioning and maintaining the quality of services.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The VHSNC plays a crucial role in the grassroots-level health planning and implementation in rural India, ensuring that health initiatives are tailored to the specific needs and conditions of the community.
  • It is a vital part of the health ecosystem, facilitating a comprehensive approach to public health management in rural settings.

Study A shows data points tightly clustered along a trend line, while Study B shows data points that are more spread out but still follow a general trend line. questions.text: While working at a rural health sub-centre, you and a medical intern are analyzing annual infant registration metrics. The intern inquires about the expected annual infant registration rate when a health worker is actively on duty at the sub center. What is the best representation of this rate? [AIIMS MAY 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) 150

 

Each year, a total of 150 infants should be enrolled at a sub-centre.

 

Annual infant population = Total population × % infants in population or expected birth rate

 

The infant population percentage, or the anticipated birth rate, ought to be derived from local data. In cases where a specific local percentage is not accessible, it is approximated at 3% of the overall population.

 

Total population in a sub centre = 5000.

 

Here, annual infant population = 5000 × 3/100 = 150

 

Total population catered by a Sub centre = 5000

 

Crude birth rate (CBR) India = 19 per 1000 Mid-year population (SRS 2016)

 

So, estimated number of births in a year = 19/1000 ×5000 = 95 births per year

 

  • Also, current Infant mortality rate (IMR) India = 28 per 1000 Live births
  • So, Expected number of infant deaths in a year in that population = 28/1000 × 95 = 2.7 deaths
  • So, total number of expected alive infants = 95 – 2.7 = 92 Infants approximately

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a rural health sub-centre, the expected annual infant registration rate effectively captures both the births and adjustments for infant mortality.
  • The number 150 serves as a practical target for ensuring all newborns are accounted for within the community health system.
  • This figure supports proactive health planning and resource allocation, emphasizing the importance of accurate and timely health data registration.

questions.text: In a busy OPD at a District hospital, you are evaluating a 5-year-old boy who presents with fever, generalized malaise, and a distinctive rash. The child's clinical presentation strongly suggests a diagnosis of measles. The mother, anxious about the contagious nature of the disease and the risk it poses to her other kids and family members, inquires about the recommended period of isolation for her infected child. What would be your most appropriate recommendation for the duration of isolation? [AIIMS MAY 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) From catarrhal stage to 4 days after rash

 

  • Patient should be advised to stay in isolation from onset of catarrhal stage to 3rd/4th day of rash.
  • Isolation is the separation for the period of communicability, of infected persons from others in such places/conditions as to prevent/limit transmission to those susceptible.

questions.text: Which influenza virus was responsible for the 2009 pandemic? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) H1N1

 

The 2009 influenza pandemic, commonly referred to as the "swine flu" pandemic, was caused by the H1N1 influenza A virus. This virus emerged in Mexico and quickly spread worldwide, causing widespread illness and leading to a global pandemic.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. H5N1: Known as the "bird flu" virus.

 

  • Year: First identified in 1997 in Hong Kong.
  • Impact: Primarily affects birds but can infect humans, causing severe respiratory illness.

 

Option C. H5N7: This subtype of influenza is not known to have caused any major pandemics or widespread outbreaks in humans.

 

Option D. H3N2: This subtype of influenza A virus is known to cause seasonal flu epidemics but was not responsible for the 2009 pandemic.

 

  • Year: H3N2 was involved in the 1968 influenza pandemic, known as the "Hong Kong flu."

 

Educational Objective:

 

Influenza Pandemics

 

SWINE FLU, H1N1 → 2009, Mexico

BIRD FLU, H7N9 → 2013, China

BIRD FLU, H5N1 → 1997, Hong Kong

BIRD FLU, H10N3 → 2021, China

questions.text:
You are employed at a primary health center (PHC) located in an area with a high risk of earthquakes. What actions would you take to ensure readiness for potential emergencies? [NEET PG 2022]

 

  1. Disaster preparedness by making sure all financial and other resources are available
  2. Increase public awareness through campaigns and loudspeakers
  3. Conduct a simulation for the disaster and assess the response
  4. Follow instructions given over the phone or radio by higher officials
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) 1,2,3

 

To ensure readiness for potential emergencies in a high-risk earthquake area, the following actions are crucial:

 

  1. Disaster Preparedness: Ensuring all financial and other resources are available. This involves mobilizing funds and resources for quick evacuation and emergency response.
  2. Increase Public Awareness: Conducting campaigns and using loudspeakers to inform the public about earthquake preparedness measures and safety protocols.
  3. Conduct a Simulation: Performing disaster simulations and assessing the response to identify areas for improvement and ensure the effectiveness of the emergency plan.

 

These steps are essential components of a comprehensive disaster preparedness strategy and done by someone working in a PHC situated in a high seismic zone. A medical officer is supposed to provide instructions by any communication method possible to manage through the calamity.

 

Roles and responsibilities of medical officer of PHC when posted in Seismic areas

 

  • Ensure funds and resources are available and can be mobilized at the time of disaster for quick evacuation
  • Preparedness to handle emergency
  • Disaster simulation practices and then check the response

 

Other Options:

 

While following instructions from higher officials is important during an actual disaster, it is not a proactive preparedness measure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Emergency preparedness is a programme of long-term development activities whose goals are to strengthen the overall capacity and capability of a country to manage efficiently all types of emergency. It involves the following steps:

 

  1. Disaster preparedness by making sure all financial and other resources are available
  2. Increase public awareness through campaigns and loudspeakers
  3. Conduct a simulation for the disaster and assess the response
  4. Evaluate the risk of disaster
  5. Information sessions coordination with news media
  6. Adopt standards and regulations

questions.text: A patient arrives with a clean-cut injury, no lacerations. He reports receiving his last tetanus vaccination approximately a decade ago. What would be the recommended course of action? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Single dose tetanus toxoid

 

The recommended course of action for a patient with a clean-cut injury who received their last tetanus vaccination approximately a decade ago is to administer a single dose of tetanus toxoid. This recommendation is based on the standard guidelines for tetanus prophylaxis in wound management.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following calculates one variable using another variable? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Coefficient of Regression

 

Coefficient of Regression can be used to calculate one variable using another variable.

 

The Coefficient of Regression is a statistical measure that assesses the strength and direction of the relationship between two variables. It is used to predict or estimate the value of one variable based on the value of another variable.

 

For example, in a regression analysis, we may want to predict a person's weight based on their height. In this case, height would be the independent variable and weight would be the dependent variable. The coefficient of regression would help us determine the relationship between these variables and enable us to make predictions about a person's weight based on their height.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The Coefficient of Correlation:  Measures the strength and direction of the linear relationship between two variables.

 

Option C.  The Coefficient of Variation: Is a measure of the relative variability of a dataset.

 

Option D. The Coefficient of Determination: Is a measure that determines the proportion of the variance in the dependent variable that is explained by the independent variable in a regression analysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Coefficient of Regression is used to calculate or predict the value of one variable based on the value of another variable, quantifying the relationship between the independent and dependent variables in regression analysis.

questions.text: A public health researcher is studying the prevalence of a disease among school-aged children in a suburban town across two separate periods during the monsoon season. Two unpaired cohorts of children are observed: one from June to July and another from August to September. To compare the prevalence rates between these two cohorts, which statistical test is most appropriate? [AIIMS MAY 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Chi square

 

  • Chi-square test can be implemented in this given scenario.
  • The data is expressed as proportion of children affected by the disease in various months.
  • It is a qualitative variable as we assess the proportion of children who are affected by the disease and those who are not affected by the disease. The chi-square test can be used to compare two or more groups.

 

Chi square: Non parametric test used for comparing percentage, proportions & fractions in two or more different group of individuals. 

 

Example: Three-fourth of MBBS students in a class are underweight whereas another class has two thirds anaemic; test of significance to be used is Chi-square test

 

Fischer’s test: Is a variant of Chi-square test when sample size is < 30

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Paired t test: Parametric test which is used to compare means (+ SD) in paired data (in same group of individuals before and after an intervention)

 

  • Example: Mean serum albumin level of dengue patients before treatment was 3.6 g/dL and after treatment was 3.2 g/dL; Comparison of mean levels can be done by Paired Student’s t-test (Unpaired Student’s t-test is for comparing means (+ SD) in two different group of individuals - Example: Mean Hb level of anemia patients was 9.6 g/dL and those of hookworm patients was 7.2 g/dL; Comparison of mean levels can be done by Unpaired Student’s t-test; Z - test: Is a variant of student’s t-test which is used when sample size is > 30)

 

Option C. Wilcoxon test: Non parametric test used for comparing percentage, proportions & fractions in matched paired data

 

  • Wilcoxon (rank sum) test: Comparing percentage, proportions & fractions in two unpaired samples
  • Mann-Whitney (Wilcoxon) test:
    • MWW is same as Wilcoxon (rank sum) test
    • Is used for assessing whether two set of observations come from same distribution (if 2 independent ‘nonpaired’ samples come from the same population)
    • ‘MWW is analogous to parametric two-sample t-test’ on the data after ranking over the combined samples
    • MWW requires calculation of ‘U statistic’.

 

Option D. ANOVA (Analysis of Variance) (F-test/F-ratio): Parametric test used to compare means (+ SD) in more than two different group of individuals

 

  • Example: Mean weight of students in class A is 50 kg, those of class B is 44.6 kg and those of class C is 52.7 kg; Comparison of mean weights can be done by ANOVA test.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text:
A team of researchers is conducting investigations to evaluate the impact of interventions targeting a specific disease. Two independent studies, labeled as A and B, are analyzed. Study A utilized an intervention denoted as "X", and Study B utilized an intervention denoted as "Y". Both studies incorporate control groups. The calculated p-values for studies A and B, with 95% confidence intervals, were found to be 0.02 and 0.001, respectively.  Based on this information, which of the following conclusions is most appropriate? [AIIMS MAY 2019]

 

  1. Study B is more precise than study A and intervention Y is more significant compared to Intervention X.
  2. Study A is more precise than study B and intervention X is more significant compared to Intervention Y.
  3. Both X and Y show a significant variation, but Study B is more significant than Study A.
  4. Both study A and B show a significant variation and both interventions have similar statistical significance.
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) If 1 and 3 are correct

 

  • Statements 1 and 3 are accurate. The p-value for study A involving intervention X within a 95% confidence interval stands at 0.02.
  • In the case of study B, employing intervention Y within the same confidence interval, the p-value is 0.001.
  • Both studies' probability (p) values fall below the 0.05 threshold (level of significance - α), leading to the conclusion that both studies A and B hold significance and thus warrant the rejection of the null hypothesis.
  • Nevertheless, study B exhibits a p-value lower than that of study A, implying that the precision and significance of study B, involving intervention Y, surpass those of study A with intervention X.

 

Other Options:

 

Option 2: This is incorrect as it mistakenly asserts that Study A, which had a higher p-value, would be more precise and that intervention X would be more significant than intervention Y. This is opposite to what the p-values suggest.

 

Option 4: Also incorrect because it suggests that both interventions have similar statistical significance, which contradicts the considerable difference in their p-values. A lower p-value in Study B indicates a stronger statistical significance compared to Study A.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In interpreting clinical study results, a lower p-value indicates stronger evidence against the null hypothesis and typically points to a more significant intervention effect.
  • In this scenario, Study B's intervention (Y) is statistically more significant than Study A's intervention (X), indicating a potentially more effective or impactful intervention.

questions.text: Dr. Radhika, the district health officer, is evaluating the efficiency of a subcenter in a rural region of India. This subcenter services a population of 5,000 people, and it has been reported that the crude birth rate (CBR) in this region stands at 20 per 1,000 people. Dr. Radhika wants to ensure that every pregnant woman receives antenatal care (ANC) to promote healthy pregnancies and reduce complications. With the current CBR, how many ANC registrations should the village health nurse (VHN) expect to handle annually? [AIIMS MAY 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) 60

 

Calculation 

 

A subcentre serves a population of 5000 in plains.

 

CBR given is 20.

 

Expected number of pregnancies can be calculated by: Birth rate x population of the area / 1000 = 20 × 5000/1000 = 100.

 

A correction factor of 10% is added to adjust for pregnancy wastage in the form of abortions or stillbirths.

 

Hence, total number of expected pregnancies = Expected number of pregnancies + 10% of the same = 100 + 10 = 110

 

 Since not all pregnancies are officially registered, an Auxiliary Nurse Midwife (ANM) is typically expected to have at least half of the anticipated pregnancies under her care registered at any point in time. Therefore, the count of Antenatal Care (ANC) registrations is calculated as 50% of the projected pregnancies.

 

Therefore, Total ANC registrations expected = total number of expected pregnancies/2 = 55

 

The closest answer is 60.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In assessing ANC needs based on CBR in a rural health setting, it's crucial to accurately apply demographic statistics to the actual population size.
  • Expectations should align with direct calculations unless specific adjustments are warranted by local conditions or policies.

questions.text: As a public health expert, you are consulted about a series of outbreaks in a region that lacks significant prior vaccination campaigns. Given the imperative to contain the spread of disease and protect vulnerable populations, you are asked to prioritize a disease for which mass vaccination would provide the most immediate and impactful reduction in transmission. Which of the following diseases would most benefit from such an intervention? [AIIMS MAY 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Polio

 

  • Mass immunization is one of the best strategies to deal with outbreak of poliomyelitis.
  • Outbreak response immunization (ORI): Following the Acute flaccid paralysis case investigation and stool specimen collection, ORI is organized in community.
  • Children aged 0-59 months are given one dose of OPV regardless of previous immunization (in the village/locality of the AFP case)
  • Travel history of the child with AFP may suggest additional places of stay where ORI should also be conducted
  • Atleast 500 children are vaccinated

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. Cholera: In case of a cholera outbreak, the most effective response would be chemoprophylaxis for a household or a closed community and. Drug of choice for chemoprophylaxis is Tetracycline.

 

Option B. Typhoid: control in case of an outbreak includes health education, water quality and sanitation improvement, prevent carriers from handling food, milk or water from others, and training of health professionals in diagnosis and treatment. Vaccination is not advised for typhoid outbreaks.

 

Option D. Tetanus: Tetanus is not a communicable disease in the traditional sense as it does not spread from person to person. Instead, it is caused by bacteria entering the body through wounds. Thus, mass vaccination for tetanus isn't typically utilized as an outbreak response but is important in routine immunization schedules.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Polio, due to its potential for rapid spread and severe outcomes, along with the availability of an effective and easily administered vaccine, makes it the most critical focus for a mass vaccination campaign in response to an outbreak.
  • This strategy not only protects individuals but also aids in the global effort to eradicate polio.

 

Additional Information

 

Outbreak response for Measles includes

 

  1. Isolation for 7 days after the onset of rash
  2. Immunization of the contacts within 2 days of exposure (if vaccine is contraindicated, immunoglobulins should be given within 3-4 days of exposure)
  3. Prompt immunization at the beginning of an epidemic is essential to limit the spread.

questions.text: A 40-year-old nurse in the infectious diseases ward is reviewing the necessary precautions for attending to patients with various primary diagnoses. For which of the following patients would she NOT need to take special airborne precautions? [AIIMS MAY 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Herpes Zoster 

 

  • While Herpes Zoster (shingles) can be contagious, it primarily requires contact precautions unless disseminated or in the immunocompromised, where it might necessitate airborne precautions if there are pulmonary symptoms.
  • Generally, for localized shingles in an immunocompetent patient, standard precautions along with contact precautions are sufficient, thus not routinely requiring airborne precautions like the diseases listed in the other options.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tuberculosis: Requires airborne precautions due to the high risk of transmission through airborne particles, particularly the respiratory droplets that can suspend in the air for extended periods.

 

Option C. Measles: Highly contagious and spreads through airborne transmission. Airborne precautions are essential due to measles' ability to remain airborne for up to two hours after the infected person has left the area.

 

Option D. Chicken Pox (Varicella): Also spread through airborne transmission, requiring similar precautions to measles to prevent the spread of the virus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Measles, Tuberculosis, and chickenpox require airborne transmission precaution unlike herpes zoster.
  • The patient should be made to wear a mask for source control.
  • A fit-tested NIOSH-approved N95 or higher-level respirator should be used by the healthcare personnel whilst care delivery.

questions.text: Which statement most accurately refers to the requirements for initiating an urban community health center? [NEET PG 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Should have a 100-bed facility in metro cities 

 

U-CHC (URBAN - COMMUNITY HEALTH CENTRE)

 

An Urban Community Health Center (U-CHC) is designed to provide inpatient care and other health services in urban areas. According to the IPHS 2022 Guidelines, the requirements for U-CHCs are as follows:

 

  • 30-50 bedded U-CHC providing inpatient care in cities (>1 per 500,000 population)
  • 75-100 bedded U-CHC facilities in metros
  • U-CHC may be set up as a satellite hospital for every 4-5 U-PHCs

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: An esteemed research institute recently conducted a comprehensive study on individuals diagnosed with HIV to understand the progression and current health status of the participants. As a part of this study, the CD4 count, which plays a critical role in assessing the immune status of these individuals, was meticulously measured. Given the graphical representation provided that depicts the distribution of CD4 counts, can you infer the average CD4 count range that can be derived from this graph? [AIIMS MAY 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) 300-400

 

If we convert the given graph data into a table, it will be as follows:


 

To determine the midpoint of each provided interval, it is necessary to calculate the midpoint for each interval individually. Following this, the resulting midpoints should be multiplied by the corresponding interval frequencies.

 

Mean = Sum of all observations / number of observations.

 

 

Mean = 34500/100 = 345.

 

Hence, 300 -400 is the answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When interpreting a frequency distribution graph like this for CD4 counts in HIV-positive individuals, it's essential to compute the weighted average based on the midpoint of each interval and the frequency of observations within each interval.
  • This provides a more accurate assessment of the overall average CD4 count, crucial for understanding the immune status in a clinical setting.

questions.text: A comparison is made between the variability present in one dataset and that in another dataset by: [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Coefficient of variation

 

The Coefficient of Variation (CV) is used to compare the relative variability of different datasets. It is a standardized measure of dispersion of a probability distribution or frequency distribution. The CV is particularly useful because it expresses the standard deviation as a percentage of the mean, making it possible to compare the degree of variation from one dataset to another, regardless of the unit of measurement or magnitude of the mean.

 

  • Co-efficient of Variation [COV] = SD/Mean x 100
  • It measures the relative variability by using the mean and standard deviation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Variance: Variance measures the spread of a set of numbers. It is the average of the squared differences from the mean. While it indicates variability, it does not provide a standardized measure for comparison between different datasets.

 

Option C. Standard Error of Mean (SEM): The SEM measures how much the sample mean of the data is likely to vary from the true population mean. It is used to understand the accuracy of the sample mean but is not used for comparing variability between datasets.

 

Option D. Standard Deviation (SD): Standard deviation is a measure of the amount of variation or dispersion in a set of values. While it indicates the spread of data points, it does not standardize this measure in relation to the mean, which is necessary for comparing different datasets.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Coefficient of Variation (CV) is the appropriate measure for comparing the relative variability of different datasets because it standardizes the measure of dispersion relative to the mean, allowing for meaningful comparisons across different datasets.

questions.text: As a researcher designing a clinical study, you are exploring methods to eliminate confounding variables, which can lead to spurious associations between the independent and dependent variables. Which of the following methods is NOT primarily used to eliminate confounders? [AIIMS MAY 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Blinding

 

  • This method is used primarily to prevent bias in the conduct and interpretation of clinical research.
  • Blinding can be of participants, investigators, or those assessing outcomes, to ensure that the behaviors and evaluations are not influenced by knowledge of which treatment or intervention participants receive.
  • While blinding reduces bias, it does not specifically address the issue of confounding variables.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Randomization: By randomly assigning participants to different groups in a study, randomization aims to evenly distribute confounding variables across all groups, thus reducing their potential impact on the outcome. This helps ensure that any differences observed between groups can more reliably be attributed to the intervention itself rather than to external variables.

 

Option C. Restriction: This involves limiting the participants in a study to certain criteria, effectively isolating specific characteristics and reducing variation that could lead to confounding. For example, a study may restrict participants to a certain age range, gender, or health status to control for these variables.

 

Option D. Matching: Matching involves pairing participants in the treatment group with similar participants in the control group based on certain characteristics (e.g., age, sex, baseline health status). This technique helps to ensure that the treatment and control groups are comparable on these characteristics, thereby controlling for confounding variables related to them.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blinding is used to remove Bias.

 

Confounding can be removed by:

 

  1. Matching (MC used /simplest)
  2. Randomisation (2nd Best Method)
  3. Restriction
  4. Stratification
  5. Statistical Modelling / Multivariate analysis (MVA)
  6. Stratified Randomization (Overall Best Method)

choices.text: Testing all the dogs for rabies
Reduce stray dog population and vaccinate all dogs

questions.text: While numerous animals play a role in the transmission of rabies, dogs stand out as the most common ones. Moreover, the impact of this disease is often more in children. Given this understanding, what approach would be both economically efficient and rational to reduce the occurrence of rabies? [NEET PG 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Reduce stray dog population and vaccinate all dogs

 

Since dogs are the primary source of infection, the most cost-effective (and logical) strategy would be Elimination of stray dogs and taking a step towards mass immunization. This approach directly addresses the primary source of infection and helps break the transmission cycle of the rabies virus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Testing all the dogs for rabies: Not economically efficient due to the large number of dogs and the high cost of testing. It also does not prevent the spread of the disease.

 

Option C. Strengthening laboratory facilities: While important for diagnosis and monitoring, this does not address the primary prevention of rabies through vaccination and control of the dog population.

 

Option D. Increase capacity of healthcare workers for surveillance: Surveillance is crucial but does not directly prevent rabies transmission. It is more of a reactive approach rather than a proactive prevention strategy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Reducing the stray dog population and vaccinating all dogs is the most economically efficient and rational approach to reduce the occurrence of rabies. This strategy directly targets the primary source of infection and helps prevent the spread of the disease.

questions.text: In which of the following analyses is monetary benefit quantified? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Cost benefit analysis

 

Cost Benefit Analysis (CBA): CBA is a method used to evaluate the total costs versus the total benefits of a project or decision in monetary terms. It helps determine whether the benefits of a project or decision outweigh the costs, thereby justifying the investment. This type of analysis assigns a monetary value to all outcomes, allowing for a direct comparison between costs and benefits. For example, the National Tuberculosis Elimination Program (NTEP) might report that it saved $12 million in a given year.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cost Effective Analysis (CEA): Definition: CEA assesses the relative costs and outcomes (effects) of different courses of action.

 

  • Output: It is measured in non-monetary terms such as health outcomes (e.g., quality-adjusted life years (QALY) saved). For instance, the NTEP might measure its effectiveness by the number of lives saved or the improvement in the quality of life.

 

Option C. Network Analysis: Definition: This is a quantitative method that involves mapping out and analyzing the sequence of activities and events in a project.

 

  • Tools: It includes techniques like Program Evaluation and Review Technique (PERT) and Critical Path Method (CPM).
  • Usage: Network analysis is used to identify the sequence of tasks, the longest path through the project (critical path), and to optimize the project schedule.

 

Option D. Input Output Analysis: Definition: This method examines the relationship between inputs and outputs in an economic system.

 

  • Application: It can include both cost-benefit and cost-effective analyses as it calculates the effects of changing inputs on the outputs. This type of analysis is often used in economics to understand how different sectors of an economy interact.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CBA [Cost Benefit Analysis] - Results of a program analyzed in terms of MONETARY benefits, e.g. NTEP (2023-24) saved 12 m US $

 

CEA [Cost Effective Analysis] - Output of a program analyzed in terms of RESULTS eg. NTEP (2023-24) save 1.7 Million people can be determined with help of QALY.

 

INPUT-OUTPUT ANALYSIS - Calculation of effects of changing the inputs (Includes CBA & CEA)

 

NETWORK ANALYSIS – It is a quantitative method. It includes activities & events. PERT is sequence of activities. CPM is the longest path in PERT.

questions.text: You are counseling a new mother about the importance of immunization for her newborn. She is particularly interested in understanding the BCG vaccine's benefits, as she has heard conflicting opinions from friends and family. Based on current evidence and guidelines, which of the following best describes the primary protective effects of the BCG vaccine in the context of tuberculosis (TB)? [AIIMS MAY 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) CNS and disseminated TB 

 

  • BCG vaccine provides protection against CNS and disseminated TB.

 

BCG Vaccine

 

  • LIVE, Attenuated, Lyophilised vaccine
  • Reconstituent – NORMAL SALINE
  • Strain DANISH–1331 (VIA M. BOVIS, 239 SC FOR 13 YR)
  • Dose 0.05 (upto 28 days, then 0.1 ml) ID, just above insertion of left deltoid
  • Efficacy 0-80% (MEDIAN-50%)
  • Dose at birth, 1 TU in 0.1 ml
  • 20 years protection {No protection against pulmonary TB}

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The BCG vaccine is primarily recommended for its effectiveness in preventing severe forms of tuberculosis, such as CNS and disseminated TB, in children.

Which of the following tasks is NOT traditionally a responsibility of the ASHA worker? [AIIMS MAY 2019]

  • ASHA (Accredited Social Health Activist) workers play a crucial role in community health, especially in rural areas of India.
  • Their responsibilities are extensive but focused primarily on preventive and promotive healthcare. But not the malaria slides preparation.
  • Preparation of malaria slides is the responsibility of health worker male.

 

Other 3 options are ASHA responsibilities

 

Educational Objective:

 

Responsibilities of ASHA:

 

  • Create awareness on health and its social determinants and mobilize the community towards local health planning and increased utilization and accountability of the existing health services
  • Promote good health practices and provide a minimum package of curative care as appropriate and feasible and make timely referrals
  • Provide information on determinants of health, on existing health services and the need for timely utilization of services
  • Counsel women on aspects of reproductive and child health
  • Mobilize the community and facilitate them in accessing health and health related services provided by the government
  • Act as a depot holder for essential provisions like ORS, IFA tablets, chloroquine, disposable delivery kits, oral pills & condoms
  • Provide primary medical care and act as DOTS provider
  • Help develop a comprehensive village health plan
  • Arrange escort/accompany pregnant women and children requiring treatment/ admission to nearest health facility
  • Be a part of JSY (Janani Suraksha Yojana) and help reduce MMR

 

Additional Information

 

Proposed population norm: 2 ASHA worker per 1000 population

 

ASHA is expected to act as,

 

  • Interface between: Community and Health care system
  • Bridge between: ANM and village
  • Accountable to: Panchayat

 

Selection criteria of ASHA:

 

  • Woman resident of local community
  • Preferably 25 – 45 years age
  • Literate with formal education up to 10th class (Relaxable for Tribal areas)

 

Indicators for Monitoring and Evaluation of ASHA’s Work

 

  • Process indicators:
    • No. of ASHAs selected
    • No. of ASHAs trained
    • % ASHAs attending review meeting after 1 year
  • Outcome indicators:
    • % newborns weighed and families counseled
    • % deliveries with skilled assistance
    • % institutional deliveries
    • % JSY claims made to ASHA
    • Completed immunized 12-23 months age group
    • % unmet need in BPL
    • % fever cases received chloroquine within 1 weeks in endemic area
  • Impact indicators:
    • Infant mortality rate (IMR)
    • Child malnutrition rates
    • No. of cases of TB/Leprosy detected as compared to last year.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman visits a clinic in Mumbai for a consultation about family planning. She discusses various options and services with her healthcare provider. During the conversation, she asks about additional health screenings included in family planning services. Which of the following screenings is NOT typically included as part of family planning services in India? [AIIMS MAY 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Screening for HIV infection

 

  • Family planning services aim to support individuals and couples in managing their reproductive health, but not all health screenings are integrated into these services:
  • Screening for HIV infection: This screening, while crucial for overall health and particularly important in prenatal care to prevent mother-to-child transmission, is generally conducted as part of broader sexual health services rather than within the narrower scope of family planning services.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Screening for cervical cancer: This is typically included because it directly relates to reproductive health and can impact a woman’s long-term health and fertility.

 

Option B. Providing services for unmarried mothers: This includes counseling and support, reflecting a comprehensive approach to reproductive health care that supports all individuals, regardless of marital status.

 

Option D. Providing adoption services: Part of family planning services that helps individuals and couples prepare for parenthood, including the option of adoption, aligning with the broad goals of family planning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Family planning is not synonymous with birth control only. A WHO Expert Committee (1970) recommends that family planning includes in its’ purview:

 

  • Proper spacing and limitation of birth
  • Advice on sterility
  • Education for parenthood
  • Sex education
  • Screening for pathological conditions related to the reproductive system (e.g., cervical cancer)
  • Genetic counselling
  • Premarital consultation and examination
  • Pregnancy tests
  • Marriage counselling
  • Preparation of couples for the first child
  • Providing services to unmarried mothers
  • Teaching home economics and nutrition
  • Providing adoption services

questions.text: In a study involving a population, where the mean value is 200, if the standard deviation is 20, 68% of the population will lie between? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) 180-220

 

In a Normal/Gaussian/Standard Distribution curve,

 

1. B/L Symmetrical Bell shaped curve

2. Mean = Median = Mode à Known as coincidence

3. If Mean = 0 in Normal Distribution, then SD is 1

4. Mean ± 1SD →Covers 68% value [68.3%]

5. Mean ± 2SD →Covers 95% value [95.4%]

6. Mean ± 3SD →Covers 99% value [99.7%]

 

So, 68% population will cover, Mean ± 1SD.

Mean = 200

Standard Deviation = 20

 

68% population will lie between = 200 ± 20 = 180 - 220

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: You are participating in a research discussion about the best approach to study the circadian changes in the fat content of expressed breast milk among mothers of preterm babies. The primary aim is to observe the variations over time and establish a temporal relationship. Which of the following study designs would be most suitable to achieve this objective? [AIIMS MAY 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Prospective Cohort

 

  • The study design of choice for the given scenario is a prospective study.
  • In the given situation, the study cohort would comprise of mothers with preterm infants, whereas the control cohort would include mothers with full-term babies.
  • To investigate the diurnal fluctuations in the fat composition of expressed breast milk, samples of breast milk would be collected at designated time points each day.
  • These samples would be monitored over the course of multiple days and subjected to analysis. This research constitutes a prospective study.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ambispective Cohort: An Ambispective cohort includes both retrospective and prospective cohort study. This case scenario will not fit in retrospective study

 

Option C. Case control: Case-control study is also a retrospective study.

 

Option D. Cross sectional: Cross-sectional study is used to figure out the prevalence of a disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A prospective cohort study is the optimal design for research that needs to observe how a variable changes over time and establish a chronological sequence of events or effects. This method will allow for the systematic collection of breast milk samples at various times to analyze changes in fat content relative to the time of day in a defined sample of mothers with preterm infants.

choices.text: COV of DBP is more than Vitamin D
COV of Vitamin D is more than DBP
Both DBP and Vitamin D have equal variability
It cannot be ascertained from information provided

questions.text: During your clinical rotations, you are reviewing data from an experiment that examined the correlation between Vitamin D levels and diastolic blood pressure (DBP). The experiment aimed to ascertain the variability within two distinct sample sets. Based on the findings, the average DBP was noted to be 110, with an associated standard deviation of 11. Similarly, the mean Vitamin D level was observed to be 18, with a standard deviation of 3. With reference to the coefficient of variation (COV), which statement accurately represents the collected data? [AIIMS MAY 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) COV of Vitamin D is more than DBP

 

Coefficient of Variation (COV)

 

  • Is a measure used to compare relative variability
  • Is a unit-free measure to compare dispersion of one variable with another
  • Is SD expressed as percentage of mean

 

 

Calculation -

 

COV of DBP = 11/110 = 0.1

 

COV of Vitamin D = 3/18 = 0.166

 

Hence, COV of Vitamin D is more than DBP

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The coefficient of variation provides a useful comparison of variability across different datasets.
  • In this case, the higher COV for Vitamin D indicates a greater relative variation compared to DBP, highlighting important considerations for researchers analyzing the impacts or associations involving these variables.

questions.text: Dr. Sharma was enthusiastically reviewing the results of a randomized controlled trial (RCT) that aimed to compare the therapeutic benefits of Drug A and Drug B. To her surprise, the data suggested a statistically significant difference between the two medications, indicated by a p-value of <0.005. However, after a comprehensive review and collaboration with other experts, it was established that in real-world settings, both drugs had essentially equivalent therapeutic outcomes. This error in interpretation, where a difference was falsely identified when none existed in reality, is best described by which of the following statistical terms? [AIIMS MAY 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Alpha error

 

  • In the given scenario, null hypothesis (H0) can be that the two drugs being the same in effectiveness is true in reality.
  • The alternative hypothesis will be that both drugs are different.
  • Since P-value was found to be < 0.005, means that data is statistically significant and thus, null hypothesis is rejected.
  • But it is already established that the null hypothesis is true and now if we accept the alternative hypothesis even though it is false, this will be a type I error or alpha error.
  • Hypothesis (H): Is an assumption about the status of a phenomenon
  • Null Hypothesis (H0): In Biostatistics, when we have to prove a particular hypothesis about difference between 2 regimens, we make Null Hypothesis (For examples, If we have to prove that new treatment is better than older treatment, H0 = new treatment is not better than older treatment).

 

Statistical errors:

 

 

Type I Error (Alpha Error):

 

  • Null hypothesis is true but rejected
  • Probability of Type I error is given by ‘P – value’ (probability of declaring a significant difference when actually it is not present)
  • Significance (a) level: is the maximum tolerable probability of Type I error
  • Alpha is fixed in advance: P – value calculated can be less than, equal to or greater than alpha (a)
  • Keep Type I error to be minimum (P < a): Then results are declared statistically significant

 

Type II Error (Beta Error):

 

  • Null hypothesis is false but not rejected (or accepted)
  • Probability of Type II error is given by beta (b) (probability of declaring no significant difference when actually it is present)

questions.text: As a medical student, you're learning about the margin of error and its relationship with sample size. With three studies of different sizes (Sample 1: 1000, Sample 2: 800, Sample 3: 600), how would you order the expected margins of error from largest to smallest? [AIIMS MAY 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) 3>2>1

 

  • Curve 1 exhibits the smallest margin of error, followed by Curve 2, and then Curve 3. Thus, the ranking is as follows: 3>2>1.
  • The depicted image showcases three normal distribution curves with varying sample sizes, all sharing the same mean but differing in standard deviation.
  • When the sample size decreases, the peak diminishes, and the curve adopts a flatter shape.
  • This signifies a broader confidence interval for the specified mean.
  • The width of the curve's base is directly linked to the margin of error.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The margin of error in a study is inversely related to the square root of the sample size.
  • This relationship implies that a larger sample size will generally lead to a smaller margin of error, assuming other variables like variance remain constant.

questions.text: Dr. Mehta, Public health expert who works extensively with the National Leprosy Eradication Programme (NLEP) in India. This rate helps in understanding the effectiveness of ongoing programs and strategies. What value did Dr. Mehta share as the ANCDR for leprosy for that specific year? [AIIMS MAY 2017]
questions.solution:

Annual New Case Detection Rate (ANCDR):

 

  • An important Indicator being used under the National Leprosy Eradication Program

Educational Objective:

 

  • The ANCDR is a pivotal indicator in disease surveillance and control programs, helping public health officials and stakeholders understand the scale of new cases and the impact of interventions.

Administer IV antibiotics and ask the patient to be brought after 24 hours

questions.text: A 2-year-old toddler with a weight of 11 kg was brought to the pediatric outpatient department. The child exhibited a respiratory rate of 38 breaths per minute and upon examination, noticeable chest indrawing was detected. What is the next step of management? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Oral amoxicillin for five days

 

According to the latest revised guidelines by WHO, the management of childhood pneumonia has been updated based on new evidence. In the given scenario, a 2-year-old child presents with a respiratory rate of 38 breaths per minute and chest indrawing, which fits the criteria for pneumonia but without general danger signs. According to the revised classification, the appropriate management for this case is oral amoxicillin for five days and home care advice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Urgent referral to the tertiary care centre immediately: This is recommended for children showing general danger signs or very severe disease, not for pneumonia with chest indrawing without other danger signs.

 

Option C. Administer IV antibiotics and ask the patient to be brought after 24 hours: This would be applicable for severe cases requiring inpatient care, not for managing a case of pneumonia without general danger signs at an outpatient department.

 

Option D. Start antipyretics urgently: While antipyretics may be used to manage fever, they do not address the underlying pneumonia and are not the primary management step in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: An investigation was conducted to evaluate the nutritional status of young children residing in both rural and urban regions. Among the participants, 30 children from rural areas and 20 children from urban areas were found to be malnourished. Which of the following tests of significance is the most appropriate in this case? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Chi Square test

 

The Chi Square test can be used to determine whether there is a significant association or relationship between two categorical variables. In this case, the two variables are the nutritional status (malnourished or not malnourished) and the location (rural or urban), both of which are Qualitative characters.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Paired T test:  is used when comparing the means of two related samples, such as before and after measurements for the same group.

 

Option C. Standard error of the mean:  is a measure of the variability of sample means.

 

Option D.  ANOVA:  is used to compare the means of three or more groups.

These tests are not appropriate for analyzing the relationship between two categorical variables as in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Chi Square test is the appropriate statistical test for evaluating the association between two categorical variables, such as nutritional status (malnourished vs. not malnourished) and location (rural vs. urban).

questions.text: During a journal club discussion on a randomized controlled trial comparing two surgical techniques for direct inguinal hernia, the reported p-value is 0.04. What is the most accurate interpretation of this p-value? [AIIMS MAY 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) The probability of a false positive conclusion that operation A is better than B is 4%

 

  • With a calculated p-value of 0.04, we can deduce that there is a 4% chance of arriving at a false positive conclusion, suggesting that operation A is superior to operation B.
  • In this context, the p-value of 0.04 attains statistical significance by conventional standards.
  • Consequently, we have grounds to reject the null hypothesis and accept the alternative hypothesis, indicating that operation A outperforms operation B.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A p-value of 0.04 suggests that there is a statistically significant difference, at the 5% significance level, between the surgical techniques being compared, assuming the risk of a false positive conclusion is acceptable at 4%.
