questions.text: A male patient who was diagnosed with tuberculosis has successfully completed the full course of treatment. Subsequent to finishing both the intensive and continuation phases, the initial sputum examination was conducted. The results of this examination were negative. What is the current condition of the patient? [NEET PG 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Cured

 

A patient with negative sputum examination at the end of tuberculosis treatment indicates that the patient has been cured of the disease.

 

Tuberculosis is an infectious disease caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis that primarily affects the lungs and causes pulmonary tuberculosis.

 

  • A TB case can be confirmed by positive results on smear microscopy and culture of biological specimens or diagnosed clinically by a clinician who prescribes a full course of TB treatment.
  • TB treatment consists of two phases: the intensive phase lasting for two months and the continuation phase lasting for four months.
  • Treatment involves four drugs in the intensive phase, namely isoniazid, rifampicin, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol, and isoniazid along with rifampicin and ethambutol in the continuation phase.
  • After completion of treatment, the patient's sputum/culture is tested and assigned one of the following outcomes: cured, treatment completed, treatment failed, lost to follow-up, died, or not evaluated, depending on the results of the test and the patient's medical history.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Treatment Completed: Refers to a patient who has completed treatment without evidence of failure but lacks documented negative sputum smear or culture results in the last month of treatment and on at least one previous occasion.

 

Option C. Lost to Follow-Up: Refers to a patient who did not start treatment or whose treatment was interrupted for two consecutive months or more.

 

Option D. Treatment Failed: Refers to a patient whose sputum smear or culture is still positive after 5 months or more of treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Terminologies:

 

  • Cured - A TB patient whose smear or culture turned negative in the last month of treatment and on at least one previous occasion
  • Treatment completed - A TB patient who completed treatment without any failure, but has no record to show that sputum smear or culture results in the last month of treatment and on at least one previous occasion were negative; it may be either because tests were not done or because results are unavailable
  • Treatment failed - A TB patient whose sputum smear or culture is still positive after treatment for 5 months or more
  • Lost to follow-up - A TB patient who did not start treatment or whose treatment was interrupted for 2 consecutive months or more
  • Died - A TB patient who dies before starting or during the course of treatment for any reason
  • Not evaluated - A TB patient for whom no treatment outcome is assigned; this includes cases "transferred out" to another treatment unit and cases for whom the treatment outcome is unknown to the reporting unit whose treatment is interrupted

questions.text: A 28-year-old man from west Garo Hill district of Meghalaya presents to the Civil Hospital with intermittent fever, chills, and malaise. Laboratory findings confirm the diagnosis of P. falciparum malaria. The region is known for its Multidrug- resistant strains of P. falciparum. Which of the following antimalarial regimens is considered the most appropriate first-line treatment for P. falciparum malaria in areas with multidrug-resistant strains? [AIIMS MAY 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Artemether plus lumefantrine

 

The Drug of choice treatment for Plasmodium falciparum infection in North Eastern states is artemether + lumefantrine

 

ARTEMISINS - ARTESUNATE AND ARTEMETHER

 

  • Fastest acting anti-malarial
  • Effective against MDR parasites
  • Short acting
  • C/I in 1st trimester

 

 Artemisinin Combination Therapy [ACT]

 

  • Artemisin + Long acting drug
  • DOC for chloroquine resistant malaria Combinations
  • Artemether + Lumefantrine: DOC in North Eastern States
  • Artesunate + Sulfadoxine-Pyrimethamine: DOC for rest of India
  • The dose of artesunate is 200 mg OD for 3 days whereas sulfadoxine (1500 mg) and pyrimethamine (75 mg) should be taken on day 1 only)

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For P. falciparum malaria in regions with known drug resistance, artemether plus lumefantrine is the most effective first-line treatment, ensuring rapid and sustained clearance of the malaria parasite.

choices.text: Artesunate 50 mg (4 tablets) + Primaquine 2.5 mg (6 tablets)
Artesunate 50 mg (4 tablets) + Primaquine 7.5 mg (6 tablets)

questions.text: A 32-year-old man from Rajasthan is diagnosed with mixed malaria infection – P. falciparum + P. vivax. Treatment regimen on Day 2 would be: [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Artesunate 50 mg (4 tablets) + Primaquine 2.5 mg (6 tablets)

 

In cases of mixed malaria infection involving P. falciparum and P. vivax, the treatment approach differs from that of single-species infections.

 

For mixed infections, the primaquine dose is adjusted to 2.5 mg to target both liver and blood stages effectively, while artesunate is used to clear the parasitemia. Artesunate is typically given for three consecutive days, and the dosage of primaquine is reduced compared to when treating only P. falciparum, where the standard dose would be 7.5 mg. This regimen helps in managing mixed malaria effectively, ensuring both species are adequately targeted.

 

Note –

 

  • For patients from other parts of the country, ACT-SP (artesunate + sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine) plus primaquine is used.
  • For patients from northeast India, artemether-lumefantrine combination therapy is preferred.
  • Primaquine in mixed infections is given for 14 days, while in single infections, it is given only on the second day.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In mixed malaria infections involving P. falciparum and P. vivax, primaquine 2.5 mg is used on Day 2 along with artesunate to effectively treat both species.

choices.text: 1/3 of the total protein requirement + ½ of total energy requirement
2/3 of the total protein requirement + ½ of total energy requirement
½ of the total protein requirement + 1/3 of total energy requirement
½ of the total protein requirement + 2/3 of total energy requirement

questions.text: Dr. Anil, working as a nutritional consultant with the government of India, is reviewing the Mid-Day Meal (MDM) scheme, an initiative to enhance the nutritional intake among school-going children. He emphasizes that the nutritional component of the meals should not just be about filling stomachs but ensuring that children get adequate protein and energy to support their growth and learning. Given the constraints and the need to ensure minimal nutritional adequacy, what should the minimum supplementation be in the Mid-Day Meal to support the children's needs? [AIIMS MAY 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) ½ of the total protein requirement + 1/3 of total energy requirement

 

  • The meal should supplement 1/3 of the total energy requirement and 1/2 of the total protein requirement.
  • Mid-day meal programme (MDMP): Also known as ‘School Lunch Programme’, it has been in operation since 1961.
  • The major objective of MDMP: To attract more children for admission to schools and retain them so that literacy improvement of children could be brought about.
  • The meal is a supplement and not a substitute to the home diet
  • The meal should supply 1/3 of the total energy requirement and 1/2 of the total protein requirement
  • MDMP is being operationalised under the Ministry of Human Resource & Development 
  • National Institute of Nutrition, Hyderabad is of the view that minimum number of feeding days in year be 250 to have the desired impact on children

 

Mid-day meal scheme (MDMS) (National Programme of Nutritional Support to Primary Education):

 

  • Launched in 1995
  • Main objective: Universalisation of primary education by increasing enrolment, retention and attendance and simultaneously impacting on nutrition of students in primary classes
  • The mid-day meal should supply 1/3 of the total energy requirement and 1/2 of the total protein requirement
  • A model menu for mid-day school meal

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Principles for formulating mid-day meals:

 

  • Meal should be a supplement only not a substitute for home diet
  • Meal should provide 1/3 calories and 1/2 proteins
  • Meal cost should be low
  • Complicated cooking process must not be involved
  • Use locally available foods
  • Keep changing menu frequently

 

Mid-Day Meal Scheme is now renamed as PM POSHAN or Pradhan Mantri Poshan Shakti Nirman.

questions.text: A drug trial was initiated under Medicine department to test the efficacy of a new medication in comparison to a placebo. The participants were divided into two cohorts. Cohort A received a placebo, while cohort B was treated with the novel drug. Out of the 120 participants in cohort A, 36 faced fatal outcomes. In cohort B, with 130 participants, there were 26 fatal outcomes. Given this data, if a clinician were to incorporate this novel medication into practice, how many patients would they need to treat with this new medication to prevent one additional fatality when compared to the placebo group? [AIIMS MAY 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) 10

 

10 patients need to be treated with the new drug to avert 1 death.

 

We can group divide the case scenario into two groups:

 

Experimental (New treatment) group – 26 Treatment failures out of 130

 

Control (Old treatment) group – 36 Treatment failures out of 120

 

 

Now, we have to calculate failure rate in both groups:

 

Experimental (New treatment) group – 26/130 = 0.2

 

Control (Old treatment) group – 36/120 = 0.3

 

 Absolute risk reduction (ARR) is the difference of failure in both groups = 0.3 – 0.2 = 0.1

 

Number needed to treat (NNT) = 1/ARR = 1/0.1 = 10

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Number Needed to Treat (NNT) is a practical measure used in decision-making for clinical interventions.
  • It represents the number of patients that need to be treated with a particular therapy over a specific period to prevent one additional bad outcome, such as death in this scenario.
  • An NNT of 10 indicates that the new medication has a significant impact in reducing fatalities compared to the placebo.

questions.text: Dr. Rathi, an obstetrician in a suburban Indian clinic, was counseling Mrs. Mehta, a software engineer, on nutritional needs during pregnancy. Mrs. Mehta has a sedentary desk job and is entering her second trimester. The doctor emphasized the significance of an appropriate caloric intake to ensure both maternal and fetal health. Given her lifestyle and the stage of pregnancy, by how much should Mrs. Mehta ideally increase her daily caloric consumption? [AIIMS MAY 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) 350 kcal/day

 

The suggested daily calorie intake for a pregnant woman in a sedentary occupation should be raised by approximately 350 calories.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pregnancy Additional Energy Requirements:
    • +350 kcal/day
  • Lactation Additional Energy Requirements:
    • 0-6 m: +600 kcal/day
    • 6-12 m: +520 kcal/day

questions.text: Which compound among the options is predominantly responsible for the disinfectant quality to bleaching powder? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Hypochlorous acid

 

The primary reason for the disinfectant ability of bleaching powder stems from the activity of hypochlorous acid, which is responsible for its effectiveness. It surpasses hypochlorite ions in effectiveness by a factor of 70-80.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypochlorite Ion (OCl⁻): While it does have disinfectant properties, it is much less effective compared to hypochlorous acid.

 

Option B. Hydrochloric Acid (HCl): This is a byproduct of the reaction between chlorine and water but does not contribute significantly to the disinfectant quality.

 

Option D. Chloride Ion (Cl⁻): This is also a byproduct of the disinfection process and does not play a direct role in the disinfectant action.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bleaching powder (CaOCl2)

 

  • 2.5 gms of bleaching powder is sufficient to disinfect 1000L of water.

 

Mechanism of action:

 

  • CHLORINE + IMPURITIES à DESTRUCTION Add some additional Cl2 [free residual Cl2]
  • Main disinfecting action of chlorine in water is due to HYPOCHLOROUS ACID [HOCL] [90% of disinfection] + Hypochlorite ions [10% of disinfection]

 

H2O + Cl → HCI + HOCI HOCI → H + OCI

questions.text: A pharmaceutical company is in the early stages of developing a new antihypertensive medication. They are planning to conduct several phases of clinical trials to assess different aspects of the drug. As part of this process, the research team is set to embark on Phase 1 of the trial. In the context of clinical trial phases, what is the primary objective of this initial phase? [AIIMS MAY 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Safety 

 

  • Phase 1 of clinical trials is critically important as it marks the first introduction of a new drug into human subjects.
  • The primary focus during this phase is to evaluate the safety of the drug.

 

Key elements assessed in Phase 1 include:

 

  • Safety & Non-toxicity.
  • Maximum Tolerated Dose (MTD.

 

Educational Objective:
